newsitem.title: JAPAN: TIFFE Euroyen futures end flat, turnover thin.
newsitem.headline: TIFFE Euroyen futures end flat, turnover thin.

text.p: Key December three-month Euroyen deposit rate futures ended Tuesday"s TIFFE day session unchanged after trading in a narrow, three-tick range.
Turnover for the day session was a thin 9,566 contracts.

The December fell to an intraday low of 99.23 in the morning, but pared losses in the afternoon as Japanese government bond (JGB) futures moved back into positive territory while Tokyo stocks extended losses, traders said.
Key March JGB futures closed up 0.03 at 126.09. The Nikkei average of 225 leading shares ended down 279.90 points or 1.49 percent at 18,470.75.

"Activity was very slow as there were no fresh incentives to trade. Unless something very dramatic comes out in overseas markets, the December could just remain stuck in the current range in coming sessions," said a city bank trader.
Traders said if the Nikkei rose above 19,000, that could prompt some selling of Euroyen futures. Still, the key contract was unlikely to fall below 99.20 that easily, they said.
The Euroyen futures market shrugged off reports about the
"As reports about Deng"s health did not dramatically move the yen/dollar, they did not have any impact on Euroyen futures," said a long-term credit bank trader.
The dollar was well-supported against the yen on concerns about Deng, but was confined in a range between 124.30 and 124.72 yen in Tokyo.
In the interbank money market, key unsecured overnight call money was traded at 0.50 percent, up from 0.49 percent on Monday.
The BOJ injected a net 100 billion yen into the money market on Tuesday morning, maintaining a neutral stance.
No new certificates of deposit (CDs) had been issued so far on Tuesday, traders said.
Three-month and two-month CDs were offered at 0.54 percent. One-month CDs were offered at 0.52 percent. All rates were unchanged from Monday.
